Community-supported agriculture (CSA) programs: With supermarkets closed, individuals could join a CSA program that connects consumers directly with local farmers. Members would receive a weekly box of fresh, seasonal produce, ensuring a steady supply of nutritious food.

Urban farming: In areas with available space, people could turn to urban farming, cultivating their own fruits, vegetables, and herbs in community gardens, rooftop gardens, or even indoor vertical farms. This would provide a reliable source of fresh produce without relying on outside suppliers.

Online farmers' markets: To adapt to the absence of traditional supermarkets, online platforms could emerge that connect farmers directly with consumers. These virtual markets would allow people to browse and purchase fresh produce, artisanal goods, and other essential items from local farmers and producers.

Food recovery networks: In the absence of supermarkets, individuals could join food recovery networks that redistribute surplus food from restaurants, cafes, and other food establishments to those in need. This would help reduce food waste while ensuring that people have access to a steady supply of nutritious food.

Bartering and trade: In a post-supermarket world, people could rely on bartering and trade to obtain food and other essential items. Communities could organize themselves into local exchange networks, exchanging goods and services based on their individual needs and skills. This would foster a sense of community and cooperation, as people worked together to ensure everyone's basic needs are met.
